q: What are the different treatments available to stop smoking?
a: There are several different treatments available to stop smoking, including nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) in the form of patches, gum, inhalators, tablets, oral strips, lozenges, nasal and mouth spray. There is also Varenicline (Champix) and Bupropion (Zyban) as alternative prescription medications. E-cigarettes can also be considered.

q: How does nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) work?
i: Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) provides a low level of nicotine without the harmful chemicals found in tobacco smoke. It helps reduce withdrawal effects like bad moods and cravings. NRT can be obtained from pharmacies, shops, and through prescription.
a: Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) works by providing a low level of nicotine without the harmful chemicals found in tobacco smoke. It helps reduce withdrawal effects like bad moods and cravings. NRT is available from pharmacies, shops, and through prescription.

q: What types of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) are available?
i: Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is available in the form of skin patches, chewing gum, inhalators, tablets, oral strips, lozenges, nasal spray, and mouth spray. Patches release nicotine slowly, while gum and sprays act more quickly.
a: Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is available in the form of skin patches, chewing gum, inhalators, tablets, oral strips, lozenges, nasal spray, and mouth spray. Patches release nicotine slowly, while gum and sprays act more quickly.

q: Is there a preferred combination of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) products?
i: Using a combination of NRT products, such as a patch with a faster-acting form like gum or spray, has been found to be more effective than using a single product. NRT treatment typically lasts 8-12 weeks, with a gradual reduction in dose.
a: Yes, using a combination of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) products, such as a patch with a faster-acting form like gum or spray, has been found to be more effective than using a single product. NRT treatment usually lasts 8-12 weeks, with a gradual reduction in dose.

q: Who can use nicotine replacement therapy (NRT)?
i: Most people, including adults and children over 12 years of age, pregnant women, and breastfeeding women can use NRT. However, it's always advisable to read the packet or leaflet and consult a doctor if you have specific medical conditions or recent heart attack or stroke.
a: Most people, including adults and children over 12 years of age, pregnant women, and breastfeeding women, can use nicotine replacement therapy (NRT). However, it's always advisable to read the packet or leaflet and consult a doctor if you have specific medical conditions or recent heart attack or stroke.

q: What are the side effects of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT)?
i: Side effects of NRT can include skin irritation with patches, irritation of the nose, throat or eyes with nasal spray, difficulty sleeping, upset stomach, and headaches. These side effects are usually mild and can be managed by adjusting the dose or type of NRT.
a: Side effects of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) can include skin irritation with patches, irritation of the nose, throat or eyes with nasal spray, difficulty sleeping, upset stomach, and headaches. These side effects are usually mild and can be managed by adjusting the dose or type of NRT.

q: What is Varenicline (Champix)?
a: Varenicline (Champix) is a medicine that helps reduce cravings for nicotine and blocks the rewarding effects of smoking. However, it is currently not available due to an impurity found in the medicine. Speak to your GP or NHS stop smoking adviser for alternative treatments.

q: What is Bupropion (Zyban)?
a: Bupropion (Zyban) is a medicine originally used to treat depression but has also been found to help people quit smoking. However, it is currently not available as it has been withdrawn by the manufacturer. Speak to your GP or NHS stop smoking adviser for alternative treatments.

q: What are e-cigarettes?
a: E-cigarettes are electronic devices that deliver nicotine in a vapor form. They allow you to inhale nicotine without most of the harmful effects of smoking. Research has shown that e-cigarettes can help you quit smoking, and they can be purchased rather than prescribed.

q: Are e-cigarettes an effective method to quit smoking?
a: Yes, research has found that e-cigarettes can help you quit smoking. They can be considered as an alternative to other medicines listed above. For maximum effectiveness, it is recommended to use e-cigarettes with support from an NHS stop smoking service.

q: What are the different treatments available to help stop smoking?
a: Several different treatments are available to help stop smoking, including nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), Varenicline (Champix), Bupropion (Zyban), and e-cigarettes.

q: Where can I get nicotine replacement therapy (NRT)?
a: NRT can be bought from pharmacies and some shops. It's also available on prescription from a doctor or NHS stop smoking service.

q: How does nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) work?
a: NRT provides you with a low level of nicotine, without the harmful chemicals present in tobacco smoke. It helps reduce withdrawal effects and cravings when you stop smoking.

q: What are the different forms of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT)?
a: NRT is available as skin patches, chewing gum, inhalators, tablets, oral strips, lozenges, nasal sprays, and mouth sprays.

q: Is it better to use a single type of NRT or a combination of products?
a: There is no evidence that any single type of NRT is more effective than another. However, using a combination of NRT products has been found to be more effective than using a single product.

q: How long does treatment with NRT usually last?
a: Treatment with NRT usually lasts 8-12 weeks, before gradually reducing the dose and eventually stopping.

q: What are the side effects of NRT?
a: Some common side effects of NRT include skin irritation, nasal/throat/eye irritation, difficulty sleeping, upset stomach, and headaches. These side effects are usually mild.

q: Is Varenicline (Champix) available for use?
a: Varenicline (Champix) is not currently available due to an impurity found in the medicine. It's unknown if it will be available again in the future.

q: Is Bupropion (Zyban) available for use?
a: Bupropion (Zyban) is not currently available. It has been withdrawn by the manufacturer, and it's unknown if it will be available again in the future.

q: Can e-cigarettes help in quitting smoking?
a: Research has found that e-cigarettes can help you quit smoking. They deliver nicotine in a vapor without the harmful effects of smoking. However, there are currently no e-cigarettes available on prescription.
